items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 5.03 mAOD at 16:45 on 22/10/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 175 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 22/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely.  River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street.  The forecast is for dry conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23 October.

items.description: The Essex coast from St Peters Flat to and including Shoeburyness and the Crouch and Roach estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Crouch, River Roach, North Sea

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1am and 3am tomorrow, Saturday 23rd October.  Tide levels will be high at Battlesbridge, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.00 mAODN at 2am, on Saturday 23rd October, which is 0.54m above tide tables, wind Force 3, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We do not expect the situation to escalate or to issue any messages for the tide following this. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message by 10am, Saturday 23rd October.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1am and 3am tomorrow, Saturday 23rd October.  Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.00 mAODN at 2am, on Saturday 23rd October, which is 0.54m above tide tables, wind Force 3, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We do not expect the situation to escalate or to issue any messages for the tide following this. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message by 10am, Saturday 23rd October.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today in the Cattershall area, however we expect levels to steadily drop throughout today 22/10/21.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening 22/10/21 or if the situation changes

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from approximately 8am today, Friday 22 October 2021 between Leatherhead and Cobham.  We expect flooding to affect land and roads.  Property flooding is not currently expected.   
Further showers are forecast over the next 5 days, though no significant rainfall is expected.  River levels remain high at Leatherhead and Downside Bridge.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
This message will be updated by 9pm Friday 22 October 2021.

River levels on the Roding remain very high, but have peaked and are falling very slowly in Abridge and Loughton. 
Flooding is likely to continue overnight 22 October, affecting low lying land, roads and gardens close to the river around Abridge and Loughton. 
Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and follow any local diversion routes where possible.
We are continuing to monitor river levels and will update this message tomorrow morning.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
The water level in Sherbourne Lake is falling but remains above the flood alert threshold as a result of heavy rainfall on Wednesday evening. This may cause some localised flooding of land in the immediate area throughout this evening, 22/10/21. However, the River Yeo at Pen Mill, the River Wriggle at Chetnole and the River Cam at Weston Bampfylde have all fallen to normal winter levels with no flood risk.
Dry weather is forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect the Sherbourne Lake level to slowly fall. We will continue to closely monitor the situation. Our incident response teams continue their checks on flood defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded, refer to local authority website for local road closures and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Saturday, 23/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are steady on the River Blackwater as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land is expected to continue, especially in the Swallowfield area. 
No further heavy rainfall is forecast for the next few days, only lighter showers, therefore we expect river levels to continue to fall, we will continue to closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening 22/10/21, or if the situation changes

The water levels in the Eastern Yar are beginning to fall from very high levels earlier in the week. This was following 55mm of rain recorded at Knighton on Wednesday (20/10/21). Currently, the river is still very high at Sandown but falling in Alverstone. Field flooding is expected along the Yar Valley. Golf Links Road will be flooded and today (22/10/21) minor impact flooding may continue to affect Moreton Common Road. Land around holiday parks in Sandown may be flooded, as water will struggle to drain to the river. Property flooding is not expected. Over the next few days, the weather will be settled and dry. In Alverstone, the river is now dropping back to normal levels and will continue to do so this afternoon. In Sandown, the river peaked around midnight (21/10/21) and is now stable and will begin to fall slowly this afternoon. During the daytime (22/10/21) it will continue to be bank full at Sandown Road Bridge. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This flood alert will be updated or removed by 10:00 on Saturday 23/10/21.

The River Arun is still high between Newbridge near Billingshurst and Pallingham Lock, following Wednesday’s rain. However, water levels are now falling, and the weather forecast is for predominantly dry days until Sunday. Minor residual flood impacts including water in fields and on roads and near isolated riverside buildings are likely to remain until at least Saturday near Pallingham Lock but will continue to ease. It will take until next week before flows are returned to normal at Pallingham Lock. The river flow through Horsham, Broadbridge Heath and Wanford has already returned to near normal. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them, while residual flood impacts remain. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 12:00 23/10/2021.

The River Arun is still high and rising, following Wednesday's heavy rain. Flooding will continue to affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Flood water will affect the A29 at Pulborough and will be extensive through nearby fields. For four hours from 0 0 30 Saturday 23/10/2021, water will be close to the tops of the banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. We are not currently expecting flooding to affect Arundel or Ford. The weather forecast is for five predominantly dry days, with the exception of possible showers Sunday and Monday. The river levels at Pulborough and Greatham Bridge appear to have peaked, but will fall very slowly. River flows will remain much higher than normal for most of next week. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 12:00 23/10/2021.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 16:15 today 22/10/21, and is forecast to reach 5.133m. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.                                               
The next tide will peak at Trowlock Island on 23/10/21 at 04:15 and will be 4.951m, therefore an alert will not be issued for this tide later today unless the situation changes, and we will continue to closely monitor this. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. The forecast is for dry conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23rd October.

River levels are now falling steadily on the Middle Dorset Stour. The forecast is dry until the second half of the weekend.
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
River levels are now falling steadily at the Hammoon gauge.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Plan driving routes to avoid road minor roads close to the river which are affected by flooding. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 23/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have remained steady on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of the recent heavy rainfall 
No further heavy rainfall is forecast for the next few days, only lighter showers, therefore we expect river levels to continue to fall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be out today checking for blockages. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening 22/10/21, or if the situation changes

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the River Pang and Sulham Brook are still high but continuing to fall. Flooding of roads and farmland  is expected to continue, especially in the Sulham area. 
No further rainfall is forecast today but there could be a few light showers tomorrow afternoon. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly overnight, tonight 22/10/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updatedtomorrow morning, 23/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 16:00 and 19:00 this afternoon, 22/10/21.  Flooding to low lying land, footpaths and roads is possible during these times and conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Areas most likely to be affected are Seaham Harbour and Docks, Seaburn Lower Promenade and Hendon Promenade. 

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation.  We will continue to monitor the forecast update this alert by 20:00 today (22/10/2021) or earlier if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the River Thame remain high but continuing to fall slowly in the Aylesbury area. Downstream of Aylesbury in Thame river levels are still high but are beginning to stabilise and should start to fall overnight . Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue, especially in the Aylesbury and Thame areas. 
No further rainfall is forecast today but there could be a few light showers tomorrow afternoon. River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from today, Friday 22 October, and for the rest of the day.  High water levels may remain into the weekend, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.    Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate or to issue any further warning messages at this time.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23 October.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from today (Friday) and for the rest of the day. High water levels may remain into the weekend, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23rd October.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from today (Friday) and for the rest of the day. High water levels may remain into the weekend, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23rd October.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high, but are expected to drop throughout today.
No further rainfall is forecast for today or tomorrow. 
We continue to closely monitor the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area checking defences and clearing trash screens.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening 22/10/21 or if the situation changes

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.09 m and is stable. 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.
Pumping is not currently taking place at Huish Episcopi pumping station. Dry weather is forecast over the next 24 hours. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to slowly decrease as a result.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Saturday, 23/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely.  River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet.  The forecast is for light rainfall during the day and into this evening. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 23 October.

The river level at Wimborne is still rising slowly, but we are confident that there will be no property flooding on the Lower River Stour
The forecast is dry until Sunday 24/10/2021 when further rainfall is expected.

items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and have fallen below levels of concern. River levels have reached their highest levels and are slowly falling but will remain sensitive to any further rainfall. The heavy rainfall experienced overnight Wednesday 20 October has cleared the area but further isolated showers are possible throughout the weekend. This is not expected to result in further impacts. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. The Environment Agency will continue to monitor the situation and issue any further updates as necessary.

The River Adur is still higher than normal, but is now significantly lower than at its recent peak, following Wednesday's rain. Minor flood impacts could remain affecting fields, rural roads and gardens. These impacts should slowly ease during Friday and over the weekend as the weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than the chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. Please continue to take care when driving on roads vulnerable to flooding, water could still make driving dangerous. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

The Western Rother is still high in Fittleworth, following Wednesday's rain. Minor flooding may still be affecting fields and gardens in Fittleworth. The river is now slowly falling along the length of the Western Rother, so flood impacts should slowly ease, returning to significantly lower levels by Sunday 24/10/2021. In Liss, Sheet, Iping, Stedham, Midhurst and communities on the Lod, river flows are already near normal. The weather forecast is for predominantly dry days until Tuesday, but with the possibility of showers Sunday and Monday. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if flood risk returns.

items.description: Cripsey Brook in Epping Forest District Council
items.message:
Following heavy rain overnight, river levels on the Cripsey Brook peaked earlier today in Moreton and Chipping Ongar and have steadily fallen back to within normal levels.
The risk of flooding has now reduced and levels are no longer a concern. 
No further flooding to low lying land and roads is expected.

River levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is dry for Saturday, with possibly some light rain on Sunday.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, though standing water may still be present. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. No further significant rain is forecast over the next five days. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

The River Ouse is continuing to fall near Barcombe, following Wednesday's heavy rain. River flows all along the upper Ouse have now fallen to near normal. Minor flooding may continue to affect fields and roads near Barcombe particularly. Flooding impacts should ease on the Ouse by Saturday 23/10/2021. The weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than the chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. Some roads mentioned in this message may still have minor flooding, so please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing and reduce flood risk. We will reissue this message if flood risk returns.

Water levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for surge conditions to subside over the next 24 hours, with no further risk from tides expected.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Enborne, Eccinswell Brook, Kingsclere Brook, Baughurst Brook, Foudry Brook, West End Brook, Bishopswood Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further showers are forecast for today and Friday is forecast to be dry. 
We continue to monitor the situation.

The Aldingbourne Rife is still high, following Wednesday's rain. However, the river is now slowly falling and the weather is forecast to remain predominantly dry for the next couple of days. Minor flood impacts will likely continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and possibly land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park, but extents and depths of water should gradually ease as the river falls through Shripney, Bersted and Aldingbourne. The lowering of water levels will be slow and the Aldingbourne Rife will remain higher than normal until next week. No flood impacts are expected in Barnham, where river levels have fallen a lot quicker, and are already close to normal flow. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. Our pumps at Felpham are running, and we will keep grilles clear through Barnham, including at the Trading Post, to reduce flood risk. We will reissue this message if the flood risk to properties increases again.

items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, though standing water may still be present. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. No further significant rain is forecast over the next five days.
We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

The River Lox is still high following Wednesday's rain, but river levels have been slowly falling overnight. Minor flood impacts could continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens during Friday, but the weather forecast is for five predominantly dry days which will allow river levels to fall and flood impacts to ease further. It might take until Saturday for river flows to return to near normal. Please continue to operate private water control structures to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, though standing water may still be present. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. No further significant rain is forecast over the next five days. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

The rivers through Hellingly have already fallen to near normal. Through Alfriston the Cuckmere River is still high, but is also slowly falling. During Friday 22/10/2021 water will remain in fields in Alfriston, and minor flood impacts could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than a chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. Minor residual flood impacts might remain, such as water in fields, gardens and on roads but these should continue to ease through the weekend. Please continue to plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding near Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is dry for for the until mid day on Sunday 24/10/2021 when further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are now falling steadily.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels in Hellingly have nearly returned to near normal following Wednesday's heavy rain. The weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than a chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. Minor residual flood impacts might remain, such as water in fields, gardens and on roads but these should continue to ease. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue messages if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

River levels have already fallen to near normal at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, following Wednesday’s rainfall. The weather outlook is for predominantly dry days until Sunday. Minor residual flood impacts might remain for a while, such as water in fields and gardens and on roads, but impacts should ease over the next few days and the risk of flooding to properties is now very low. There is the possibility of unsettled weather returning next week, so please remain prepared. We continue to operate our assets that help maintain water levels. We will reissue our flood warning when the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is still higher than normal, but is now significantly lower than at its recent peak, following Wednesday's rain. Minor flood impacts could remain affecting fields, rural roads and gardens. These impacts should slowly ease during Friday and over the weekend as the weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than the chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. Please continue to take care when driving on roads vulnerable to flooding, water could still make driving dangerous. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.description: River Clyst from Broadclyst to Clyst St. Mary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding has now reduced, and have fallen below levels of concern. River levels have reached their highest levels and are slowly falling but will remain sensitive to any further rainfall. The heavy rainfall experienced on Wednesday night has cleared the area but further isolated showers are possible throughout the weekend. This is not expected to result in further impacts. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. The Environment Agency will continue to monitor the situation and issue any further updates as necessary.

Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett, Lower Reaches

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
     
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

The River Ouse is still high near Barcombe, following Wednesday's heavy rainfall. However, water levels have fallen from Thursday's peak. Minor flooding will continue to affect the Anchor Inn, Anchor Lane and Barcombe Mills Road until Friday evening. A flood alert remains in force to communicate these impacts, and the extensive water through nearby fields that will continue until the weekend. However, the weather forecast is for 5 predominantly dry days, other than the chance of an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. No new property flooding is expected in Barcombe so we are removing this flood warning. Some roads may be affected by flood water, including those mentioned within this message. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will reissue this flood warning if the risk of property flooding increases.

items.message:
River levels on the Crane have dropped through the day, and are back to within normal levels. The river will no longer pose a risk of flooding at high tide.
No further flooding to low lying land and roads is expected.

items.description: Lower Stour from Sturminster Marshall to Christchurch

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. A Flood Alert remains in force on the Lower Stour
The forecast is dry until mid day on Sunday 24/10/2021 when further rainfall is forecast.
River levels are rising steadily, but there is no longer a risk of properties being flooded
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The River Arun is still high following Wednesday's heavy rain. Flooding will continue to affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Flood water will also continue to affect the A29 at Pulborough, and may still be extensive through nearby fields and gardens. The weather forecast predicts five predominantly dry days ahead, other than an isolated shower on Sunday and Monday. This will allow water levels to fall in Pulborough. River levels will fall very slowly, so will still be higher than normal this weekend. It will take a week of dry weather before river flows return to normal. Some roads included in this message may still be impassable, as a precaution please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, such as the A29 to Pulborough. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 10:00 23/10/2021.
